ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: HIST 205 with Profesor Lamont is a great way to get into history at Yale. The content was very interesting and you will do well so long as you pay attention in lecture and interact in section. The response papers provide a fairly low pressure opportunity to interact with current scholarship on aspects of ancient Greek society such as poverty and imperialism.
I got a good introduction to Ancient Greek history along with a greater comfort with the chronology.
I gained an introduction to ancient Greek History, ranging from the Minoans to Alexander the Great.
A great overview of Greek History from the Minoan times up to Alexander the Great. This is a perfect introduction to Ancient Greek History
A working knowledge of the foundations of Ancient Greek poleis, the relations between the poleis of the Ancient Greek world.
Leaned a ton about Ancient Greece
I learned a general overview of Greek history from the Mycenaean Age to the reign of Alexander the Great, including the main figures, events, and wars.
I learned about ancient Greek history from the Minoan era to Alexander the Great.
How to better write Response papers.

Greek history (mostly political) of the Minoan and Mycenaean period, the Archaic Period, the Persian Wars, the Classical Period, the Peloponnesian War, Spartan and Theban hegemony, and the rise of Macedon. Adhered pretty closely to the Pomeroy textbook, so you can glance through to see if it seems interesting.
For the most part this class was about memorizing the material. I enjoyed the significant engagement with primary texts, especially Herodotus, Thucydides, and Plutarch. There were also two essays requiring us to understand and respond to modern scholarship.
Greater knowledge about Ancient Greece from 1200-300s BC. Different polis, wars, themes in Greek History. Learned about famous Greek historians and storytellers and used their work as primary texts.
I learned a lot about Greek History and the trends within their cultural advancements.
Lots of greek history.
A solid, comprehensive, rich picture of the Greek world from the Bronze Age to Alexander the Great. Exactly what I was looking for.
Knowledge of Greek history from the Mycenae to the rule of Alexander

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - Section! You have the opportunity to take a section with this course and you absolutely should. Topics covered in discussion are interesting and the TF's mediate a fun dialogue around the content in lecture every week. 
-Profesor Lamont's Lectures are very engaging and she does a good job at allowing student's to ask questions as she moves through the content. She is extremely knowledgable and impressive to watch explore the story of Ancient Greece. 
-Tests in this class are also a strength. While requiring a good understanding of the content, they are written quite fairly and will not cripple your grade so long as you go to lecture and pay attention. 

Weaknesses - The level and quantity of readings in this course are fairly high, however, if you have to sacrifice the textbook readings and focus on the primary sources (Herodotus, Thucydides, Plutarch, etc...) you will most likely be fine.
I think the course is very well paced.

Strengths: Greek history is endlessly fascinating, and Professor Lamont does an excellent job of telling the story of ancient Greece in a way that is organized, insightful, and engaging. She also picks really fascinating scholarly articles for the reading response assignments. 

Weaknesses: None!

Strengths--fantastic course. Lectures were engaging, readings very short, exams very fair. Almost no complaints whatsoever. Prof Lamont is incredible.

Weaknesses--not much, but this course is introductory, so I wouldn't recommend it if you already have college-level classroom experience with Ancient Greece. The multiple choice are weighted too much on exams (5 points for 1 little question). Should be more multiple choice but less weight on each
This course was well organized and offered various levels of flexibility to students' academic calendars with its no section option and flexible essay dates

I feel like this class is a little bit too Atheno-centric and might benefit from more sources outside the traditional canon. Incorporating Xenophon or perhaps some plays would be interesting. Otherwise this was a riveting course which I really enjoyed
Great prof

The course did a good job of providing a general overview of ancient Greek history, and I feel like I got a sense of all the main points and "greatest hits." However, the class was more military history-focused than I initially realized when I signed up, and it would have been nice to have more of a focus on society/social history, as I really appreciated when Prof. Lamont did bring in examples of things like material culture and societal customs.
The course was great.

I really appreciated how thorough an understanding of the period I felt I had by the end of the semester. I think I'd be prepared for more advanced courses because I learned all the fundamental people, places, dates, and events of Ancient Greece. I also thought it was great to read from classic primary sources like Herodotus and Thucydides.
Sometimes, I thought the lectures were a little dry, because they were mostly a chronological journey through all the key events. I would have enjoyed hearing Professor Lamont deliver arguments about how she interprets things, which would be less objective but . In my opinion, the course would also be served by looking a little more into the non-political aspects of Ancient Greece, such as philosophy or art. Lastly, because we never really discussed them, the modern articles we we wrote essays on felt tangential and not part of a cohesive whole with lectures and discussion sections.

The strength of this class lies mostly in how interesting Greek history and the great arcs in it, which Professor Lamont supplements with interesting details. This class was ultimately made for me, however, by my TA. Though sections are optional, I found it made the class much more fun! I highly recommend.
It was very interesting and engaging.

This class does a great job surveying Ancient Greek history and the basis of western civilization by looking at primary sources, art, architecture, and myths. Lectures do a good job covering the "story" of Ancient Greece and sections, although optional, are great to review material and primary sources. In terms of assignments and grading, Professor Lamont gives you a ton of flexibility and is very fair in all of her exams. In terms of weaknesses, sometimes the chronological march through the history of Ancient Greece felt a bit one-dimensional; it would have nice to stop and look at daily life of citizens, for example. Of course, the nature of the primary sources often prevent us from doing this and this is a survey course for a large amount of time in the end.

I see no weaknesses. The course was excellently designed to give the student a detailed overview of Ancient Greece, and the Pomeroy textbook helped provide details regarding culture and daily life which were unsuitable to dwell on in the politically and institutionally focused lectures.
It was interesting material that could have been organized better

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. If you are interesting in learning about Ancient Greece, Athenian democracy, ancient wars, and more, this is totally a class to take. Professor Lamont's lectures come together to tell one big story about Greece from 3400-300BCE that was a pleasure to learn from.

I would recommend this course. The subject matter is fascinating, even to someone who is studying a completely different field (I'm not a classics or history major and took this course entirely for fun). The lectures are engaging and the readings are interesting.

Yes! Highly, highly recommend the class to anyone interested in learning about the birth of the West. Greek history is so interesting and Professor Lamont does a fantastic job of teaching the course. I loved the flexibility granted by the class (optional sections, choosing from 2/5 reading response papers).

Would strongly recommend to anyone remotely interested in Ancient Greek history. I'm a classics major, but I would equally recommend this course to someone who is not. Prof Lamont makes every lecture so enjoyable
I would recommend this course to another student
Yeah it was great
I would recommend if you're interested in gaining an overview of ancient Greek history and are interested in military history, as that is a lot of what this course covers.
Lamont is great, the TFs were great, great course.

I'd definitely recommend it. I came in first and foremost wanting to learn all about the key people and events that shaped the Ancient Greek world, and that's exactly what I took away. The workload was not bad at all (I read the textbook and all the primary sources, but you could definitely get away with less if you're willing to lose out on some of the finer details), and I was especially glad to write two four-page essays rather than a term paper which would have brought me tons of stress for very little reward.
Yes!
Anyone who is interested in Greek History or who loves classic civilizations should definitely take this class.
Yes! It was an interesting and easy history course.
I would definitely recommend this course. It provides an in-depth survey of Ancient Greek history and presents the information in a very digestible way.
If you want to know more about greek history, take this course.

If you are at all curious about Ancient Greece, then yes! Professor Lamont is a wonderful lecturer and historian - her enthusiasm and expertise during lecture are amazing. The workload is not too bad, as long as you keep up with readings and go to lecture (and section, even though it's optional). Lots of flexibility in writing assignments and exams are fair, although a decent amount of memorization. It's a challenge to go through such a huge chunk of history in a semester and as such, it can feel a bit rushed and monotonous at times. But as long as you have a curiosity for Ancient Greek history and engage in section, this class will be really good.
Absolutely. If you are looking for a comprehensive overview of Ancient Greek history, look no further.
If they are interested in civilizations throughout history

extras.title: CLCV 205 01/HIST 205 01 - Intro to Ancient Greek History
